Remember ADS-B Exchange? The flight tracking website run by hobbyists, unlike the more commercialized FlightRadar24?

Well, they sold their soul now, for $20M.
https://www.jetnet.com/news/jetnet-acquires-ads-b-exchange.html

Apparently the owner didn't inform, let alone ask, the ~ 10k people feeding data into it.

#ADSBExchange #FlightRadar24 #capitalism

title: Nevada Governor Turns to Lobbyist Tied to COVID Lab Scandal for Help With Budget

last_post.content:
“During his contentious campaign to become Nevada governor, Joe Lombardo accused the Democratic incumbent of catering to the family of a donor and their lobbyist who helped an error-prone COVID-19 testing lab get licensed in the state.
“Shortly after he won the race, Lombardo, a Republican, quietly turned to that same lobbyist for help building the state budget, giving him access to confidential documents and putting him in a position that allowed him to advocate for state funding sought by his clients.”
https://www.propublica.org/article/nevada-lombardo-northshore-covid-sisolak-willden

This is a really interesting study. When Black newborns are cared for by Black physicians, their "clinical penalty" that is the difference in mortality from white newborns is halved.

What's fascinating, if you dive in, is that this is despite the fact that Black physicians tend to have higher caseloads, and also tend to serve more underresourced patients.

Things that make you go hmmmmm...

https://www.pnas.org/doi/10.1073/pnas.1913405117

HT: @TheRaDR

title: Working from home saves employees 2 hours a week in commute time, and they’re spending it in ways CEOs don’t expect

last_post.content:
Study of 27 countries finds the average daily time savings for remote work is 72 min per person. Workers allocate 40% of the saved time to their jobs, 11% to caregiving, and 34% to leisure.
https://fortune.com/2023/01/24/worker-productivity-spend-commute-time-working/

title: How To Practice “Productive Procrastination” - Clive Thompson - Medium

last_post.content:
"How to Practice 'Productive Procrastination'"

An essay in which I meditate on the idea of inventor Saul Griffith ...

... which is:

Pick some side "learning projects" -- little things you want to do that require you to pick up a new skill

Then when you can't face work ...

... do one of your side projects for a bit

It's -- worked for me? My essay on it: https://clivethompson.medium.com/how-to-practice-productive-procrastination-e2522247bd07

(If you're not a Medium subscriber, here's a "friend" link: https://clivethompson.medium.com/how-to-practice-productive-procrastination-e2522247bd07?sk=c43f6ca1b4b098052e77175cb834a758)

One of those services is:
acm - AWS Certificate Manager (ACM)

Unfortunately, this command shows no quotas for the ACM service.

$ aws service-quotas \
list-service-quotas \
--service-code acm
{
"Quotas": []
}

even though we know the ACM service has quotas, and they even have quota codes:

https://us-east-1.console.aws.amazon.com/servicequotas/home/services/acm/quotas/L-FB94F0B0

The ARN for the above has a service code of "acm" and a quota code of "L-FB94F0B0", so we know we're looking in the right place in the cli.

4/

title: The Journal of Slavery and Data Preservation

I have been using the Freedmen's Teacher Project data set a lot and it's been invaluable. It contains information on 11,000+ freedmen's teachers including who sponsored them and basic demographic info. Today I'm using it to research educators at Talladega College during reconstruction. Follow along if you want to see what I've learned today.

You can download the data as an excel spreadsheet at this link: https://jsdp.enslaved.org/fullDataArticle/volume3-issue1-freedmens-teacher-project/

Here is how #platforms die: first, they are good to their users; then they abuse their users to make things better for their business customers; finally, they abuse those business customers to claw back all the value for themselves. Then, they die.

If you'd like an essay-formatted version of this thread to read or share, here's a link to it on pluralistic.net, my surveillance-free, ad-free, tracker-free blog:

https://pluralistic.net/2023/01/21/potemkin-ai/#hey-guys

Ok, so.

Tweets look really good when you send them in Messages on iOS/macOS. Mastodon posts… don’t. So I built a little tool that makes them much nicer to look at:

https://mstdn.link

Add ?to={any Mastodon post URL} to the end of that domain and when you send it to a friend, you get the nice looking preview. Of course the page makes it easy to paste a URL in. And there’s a Shortcut to make it even easier on iOS or macOS.

title: 1.2-Million-Year-Old Obsidian Axe Factory Found In Ethiopia

last_post.content:
1.2 *million* year old workshop for making cutting tools (hand axes) from obsidian found in Ethiopia. Until now it has been the consensus that making tools from obsidian was rare until the comparatively recent Middle Stone Age (mesolithic).

This was long before modern humans (homo sapiens) emerged, so this was a trained process by one of our ancestor hominins.
#archaeology #paleontology
https://www.iflscience.com/1-2-million-year-old-obsidian-axe-factory-found-in-ethiopia-67232
I've been really enjoying Origin Story by @iandunt and Dorian Lynskey. This episode on Fascism is incredibly good https://pca.st/episode/4923c7f1-af05-40f3-af7b-ba7dab895ee3

Happy to share @logseq graphs can take part in the #LinkedData ecosystem.😄 See https://github.com/logseq/nbb-logseq/blob/main/examples/linked-data/README.md#write-rdf for an example script that converts a subset of a Logseq graph to a #RDF file. The example demonstrates that a portion of Logseq's docs can be translated to rdf

Research papers increasingly refer to websites like GitHub for code, which may be a problem...

About 20% of preprints referred to GitHub in 2021. Yet, these web pages are often not archived, jeopardizing their long-term availability.

"The growing use of Git Hosting Platforms in scholarly publications points to an urgent and growing need for dedicated efforts to archive their holdings in order to preserve research code"

via https://doi.org/10.48550/arXiv.2208.04895
#OpenScience #OpenSource @academicchatter

You should read @Mer__edith's thread on all this,¹ and it's worth remembering what @signalapp does and does not do.

Signal does not protect you from:
• an untrustworthy chat partner
• a compromised device
• corporate device management
• your device's Operating System

Signal does protect you from:
• a hack of the Signal servers
• a subpoena of the Signal servers
• the wire between you and the Signal servers
• the employees at Signal

¹ https://mastodon.world/@Mer__edith/109751701529562752

title: Exclusive: Treasury helped Putin ally sue UK journalist

last_post.content:
If you're tuning in to this story from outside the U.K. you won't believe it, but it's true.

Yevgeny Prighozin is head of Russian mercenary group Wagner. He's been sanctioned in the U.K since 2019.

The U.K. government overrode their own sanctions to allow Prighozin to pursue a libel case against a U.K. journalist in a U.K. court using a U.K. law firm.

And what was the libel case about?
The journalist said Prigozhin was the head of Russian mercenary group Wagner...

https://www.opendemocracy.net/en/prigozhin-government-russia-ukraine-hack-libel-slapp/

I've been working on the Strange Beast Tarot for months, and now I'm crowdfunding the full deck! It is a hand-painted watercolor bestiary, full of the marks and stray lines of hand-craft, of odd forms, curious gods, and creatures who are unsure about their place in this universe.

I'm raising money to fund a couple months of intense and devoted painting and production work and to make the prettiest deck that I can!

title: Reaching 80% zero-shot accuracy with OpenCLIP: ViT-G/14 trained on LAION-2B | LAION

last_post.content:
RT @laion_ai@twitter.com

We release a new ViT-G/14 CLIP model with OpenCLIP which achieves 80.1% zero-shot accuracy on ImageNet and 74.9% zero-shot image retrieval (Recall@5) on MS COCO. As of January 2023, this is the best open source CLIP model.

title: Experian Glitch Exposing Credit Files Lasted 47 Days – Krebs on Security

last_post.content:
Experian has officially acknowledged my Dec. 23 report to them about a security weakness that exposed any consumer's credit file if you knew their name, address, SSN and DoB.

Experian says the weakness persisted on their site for 47 days, from Nov. 9, 2022 until three days after I notified them.

New story here:
https://krebsonsecurity.com/2023/01/experian-glitch-exposing-credit-files-lasted-47-days/

I am good at explaining recondite financial concepts in plain English. But @matt_levine is, without a doubt, the best. His piece today on yesterday's NYSE glitch should be on the permanent syllabus for Knight-Bagehot fellows etc. https://www.bloomberg.com/opinion/articles/2023-01-25/nyse-forgot-to-open-yesterday

#thingsthatcaughtmyattention

As you might have seen in the last boost, I've started a new server directory site to help people sign up on Mastodon and the Fediverse:

➡️ https://fedi.garden

If you want to follow the project, its account is at:

➡️ @FediGarden

Reasons for making this directory:

-It will list both Mastodon and non-Mastodon servers.
-It has a maximum size, megaservers aren't listed.
-It's manually curated and has safety/reliability requirements.

As far as I know, no one else is doing this.

I wonder why my colleagues have had such a different experience.

My best guess is that most people don't attempt to debug what my colleagues would consider a hard bug (when it's possible to get a repro, these often take days or weeks to even get an unreliable repro and you don't know in advance if you'll get a repro; per https://www.patreon.com/posts/27316256, I've run into quite a few people who've never spent more than a day debugging something, let alone looking for a repro).

Some people at the FT set up a Mastodon instance and quickly discovered it's way more work and risk for a corporation than it was worth.

RIP Paul David, the original economic historian of path dependency and technological lock-in.
He lives in the ideas he developed, many of which around e.g. the new economics of science, are yet to be exploited fully. Read this if you haven’t already: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/0048733394010021

RT @timobres@twitter.com

I report, with great sadness, the passing of Paul David. A fabulous scholar of economic history and the economics of technology, he lit up Stanford for six decades. https://siepr.stanford.edu/people/paul-david

While I get that this is an easy take on Mastodon.. what if it's totally fine that not everyone needs to join Mastodon?

Mastodon breaks the mold of how people think of product growth.. and that's fine. Mastodon is *not* all about engagement. That's the point! Quality of community, content and discourse above all else. I'm happier here with 5% of the audience I have on Twitter.

Not to say there isn't progress to be made w/ onboarding & core mechanics, things i mention in https://paulstamatiou.com/mastodon/

@davew Saw your piece on zettlekasten. Tools for thought clearly in your genes :). I read this book earlier in the year https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/34507927-how-to-take-smart-notes that is one a lot of the zettlekasten people push. Made me a little less gung ho about it. It's really more for academic/large writing. But the magical something will only happen if your are constantly reviewing/createing/thinking about the notes like your uncle and luhman were. I think a lot of people forego that part. Either way good piece.

Movie Review: TiMER

It's rare to find a sci-fi / rom-com crossover - and it's even rarer to find one that's good. TiMER is excellent. Like all good speculative fiction, it changes just one aspect of the modern world - what would it be like if you knew exactly when you would meet your one-true-love?

It doesn't bother much with the science part of sci-fi, it goes straight for the paradox. If you knew -

https://shkspr.mobi/blog/2021/01/movie-review-timer/

#/etc/ #moviereview #scifi

When we wrote this book chapter on copyright issues related to generative AI in 2018, I couldn't imagine how timely it would become in a couple of years:

"AI-generated content: authorship and inventorship in the age of artificial intelligence", Rosa Maria Ballardini, Kan He, and Teemu Roos
